救生员https://lifehacker.com/feed/rss做得更好。 Mon, 24 Feb 2025 15:13:43 +0000 En-us 星期一，2025年2月24日15:13:43 +0000版权2025 Ziff Davis，LLC。版权所有。 15小时1 苹果为何关闭英国的高级数据保护（这对每个人意味着什么） 01JMVXD9BQTV3PYT9NS94Z71N3 Mon, 24 Feb 2025 15:00:00 +0000关于端到端加密的辩论重新开始。

If you want your iCloud data to be as well-protected as possible, you need to turn on Advanced Data Protection (ADP)— but that's no longer going to be an option in the UK.据报道，苹果正在从该国撤出ADP，据报道，英国政府要求将后门送入加密iCloud文件，而后果可能会带来全球后果。

什么是ADP？

ADP应用了端到端加密（数据安全性的黄金标准），几乎是您在iCloud中得到备份的所有内容，从而使其他任何人都无法访问它。如果未启用ADP，则只有某些类型的数据得到此保护，例如密码和付款信息，iCloud中的消息以及您的健康数据。重要的是要注意，这些数据仍然完全受到所有人的保护，即使是苹果和英国间谍。

没有ADP，您的其余iCloud备份（例如，想想iCloud驱动器，照片和注释）仍然受到保护，但加密级别。该保护在防止坏演员并防止您的数据被黑客攻击方面做得非常好，但是如果Apple员工的要求，仍然可以访问它，并且对于当前的故事至关重要 - 政府和执法机构。

尽管苹果公司以及世界各国政府和安全服务都会告诉您，在可以获取加密数据的人方面，他们已经进行了强大的检查，但访问的可能性仍然存在。随着ADP（以及其他部署端到端加密的位置，例如WhatsApp），可能性就会消失。即使FBI或MI5要求文件也无法交付。

Earlier this month, The Washington Post reported that UK officials had requested secret, backdoor access into Apple's fully encrypted data files.显然，根据《 2016年调查权法》的主持人提出了需求，该法案使该国的安全服务以调查犯罪活动的名义广泛地访问用户数据：与恐怖主义和停止虐待儿童虐待是创建加密的两个常见原因后门。

这场战斗已经进行了多年。政府和执法机构希望自己的特殊钥匙到保护世界各地的用户数据的锁，表面上是为了阻止犯罪分子。像苹果这样的隐私活动家和科技公司认为，没有有效的方法将后门限制为“好人”，而不是“坏人”（即使很容易区分两者，这也不是）。

苹果在英国的举动以及全球的含义

英国的用户现在看到这样的消息。信用：Lifehacker

苹果的政策长期以来一直是它永远不会为其加密数据提供后门，因此似乎已经决定唯一的其他选择是提取ADP。没有ADP启用的英国人无法再将其打开，而确实设置了该功能的人将不得不将其关闭（尽管苹果没有说什么）。

"Apple can no longer offer Advanced Data Protection (ADP) in the United Kingdom to new users and current UK users will eventually need to disable this security feature," Apple spokesperson Julien Trosdorf told The Verge . “我们感到非常失望的是，鉴于数据泄露和对客户隐私的其他威胁，ADP提供的保护将无法为我们的客户提供。”

正如您所期望的那样，鉴于该问题的敏感性，英国的政府官员尚未对报道的内容说什么，而且您也不会直接提及它，因为宣传调查中的需求权力法本身就是刑事犯罪。

至于其他组织，例如Google和Meta，我们仍然处于黑暗状态。大概英国政府也提出了相同的要求，但细节尚未泄漏，没有人可以谈论它。像苹果一样，Google和Meta反复表示反对加密后门。

如果您在英国（像我一样），那是一团糟，但会影响所有人：鉴于我们现在在互联网时代拥有的国家边界相当模糊，英国机构很可能能够访问端到端的加密来自世界各地的用户通过此后门的数据，目前看着桌子。

我已经打开了ADP，但是除非解决问题，否则我必须尽快将其关闭，这意味着我的一些iCloud数据更容易再次窥探。通常，普通用户最终失去了损失，而加密后门的辩论也在爆发。

什么是“ Amialivecore”？

On his substack " The Trend Report ," Kyle Raymond Fitzpatrick pulled together a ton of disparate cultural expressions among online youth to identify a style he calls "Amialivecore."菲茨帕特里克（Fitzpatrick）认为，年轻人在潜意识中不确定他们真的是活着的人。我认为他正在做某事。

我对Amialivecore的含义的解释：由于他们是婴儿，所以年轻人的经历几乎完全是虚幻的。一切都是调解的。他们在视频游戏中有“经验”。他们通过Tiktok视频的垂直窗口看到了世界。他们只在在线帖子中看到朋友。他们从模因建立个人哲学。 Meanwhile, the companies and algorithms behind the social media platforms and video games have gotten really good at dehumanization. They've identified, commodified, and shaped their dreams, desires, thoughts, and feelings so thoroughly, it's impossible for young people to know how to live authentically.因此，他们玩耍并创建内容代替生活。有了证据，请去看一个像孩子一样的乐队，并比较有多少人拿出手机来拍摄视频以及有多少人在跳舞。

According to Fitzpatrick, seemingly unrelated things like the TikTok trend of dropping objects on your feet and rating how much they hurt, wearing visible tape on your face in public , and spending your time consciously trying to find a personal style illustrate young people attempting to "问题解决了您是否还活着以及您的身体是否有效以及您是否确实存在的问题。”

也许吃蝴蝶并突然变成哥特也是Amialivecore的表达。

青少年是否将蝴蝶注入在线挑战的一部分？

不。

I can't find any evidence of an "online challenge" involving injecting yourself with a butterfly, but that's what some sources claim inspired a Brazilian 14-year-old to crush a butterfly, mix it with water, and inject it into his leg 。戴维·纳尼斯·莫雷拉（Davi Nunes Moreira）的事情糟糕透顶：经过一周的痛苦症状后，他在巴西平面的一家医院死亡。

医疗专业人员不确定是什么是什么原因造成了青少年的死亡：这可能是一种过敏反应，感染，栓塞或蝴蝶本身可能是有毒的。重点是，向自己注入蝴蝶是一个坏主意，但报告几乎绝对不存在的“在线挑战”也是一个坏主意。自人们首次出来以来，人们一直以愚蠢的方式自杀。

我对模因的几代人的年龄增长，首次面对成人情况，并通过模因互相告知/告知彼此，这让我着迷。这就是本周淹没社交媒体的“工作变得重要”模因背后的氛围。这个想法是将“意外在工作上变得重要”的短语附加到表达您在工作中“注意到”时发生的情况的图像。这里有一些例子：

在语中，“光环”一词描述了一个神秘而酷的人。这是一件积极的事情。另一方面，“光环耕种”是模棱两可的。根据上下文的不同，它可以指的是一个无需尝试的人，或者一个努力看起来很酷的人。一切都与上下文有关。

哥特回来了（并不是说它真的去过任何地方）

就像启发它的吸血鬼一样，哥特从未真正死亡。它只是在棺材上睡觉，直到该宣称新受害者为止。 Judging from TikTok, the dark aesthetic and gloomy vibe of the subculture is gaining ground with young people ; maybe it's based on the recent reboot of Nosferatu or maybe it's just because goth fits the times.

虽然一些哥特（Goth）的标记是多年生的哥特（Goth）标记（黑色的衣服，欢乐师），这一代人对氛围的表达在关键方面与祖父母在1980年代初对它的解释的关键方式有所不同。也许是因为我正在考虑Amialivecore，但是Nu-Goths似乎更像是一个姿势，而不是生活方式。与过去的几代人相比，外观更弯曲到戏剧和豪华的狂欢。今天的哥特感觉更加故意和自我意识，就像孩子们买了衣服一样，看着一些化妆教程，然后说：“现在我是哥特！”旧的哥特人倾向于苍白，自杀的瘾君子，使其他人称其为“哥特”。

; https://lifehacker.com/entertainment/the-out-of-touch-adults-guide-to-kid-culture-what-what-is-amialivecore?utm_medium = rss斯蒂芬·约翰逊Entertainment 找到您附近的跑步轨道的最佳方法（以及初学者的锻炼） 1850830346 Mon, 24 Feb 2025 14:00:00 +0000大多数学校曲目向公众开放。这是找到一个方法，并在那里浏览礼节。

If you want to become a faster runner, you'll probably end up doing a lot of speedwork on a track.或者，如果您住在一个丘陵的地方，您可能希望自己有一条不错的平坦轨道。但是，您如何找到向公众开放的呢？事实证明，这比您想象的要容易。许多公立高中曲目都可以供社区使用。

致电当地学校

口口相传是找到最佳本地曲目的最佳选择；保证您社区中有大量人知道哪些学校有开放的道路。您可以询问跑步者，询问父母（他们会非常了解学校），或者削减中间人并打电话给学校。

我在当地的学校轨道上跑步，而我发现它非常简单。我打电话给最近的高中，问他们是否有向公众开放的曲目。他们说是的，只要我到上学时间；但是他们还建议在同一地区有一所不同的学校，该学校的赛道计划较少。那是我现在最经常运行的曲目。我发现学校并不总是在网上放置他们的田径政策（或位置！），因此老式的电话确实是获得此信息的最快方法。您还可以亲自访问学校（请之后），并寻找表明赛道何时以及是否向公众开放的迹象。

请注意，即使在下班后，也可能会有田径比赛，足球比赛或其他使用学校设施的活动。通常，在球队在内场练习时，可以在赛道上跑步，但是如果不确定，请找到教练并问。 （我只要求我一次离开赛道，而教练对此非常有礼貌，在团队开始练习之前，我给了我10分钟的警告，以便我可以结束我的锻炼。）您也可以查找学校或地区的运动时间表，在您离开家之前检查是否安排了当天的赛道活动。

使用轨道目录

Another great resource for finding tracks is Run Track Run , which lists tracks and running routes across the US Some of the tracks have information listed, such as the type of surface, whether it's open to the public, and whether it's free to use.当地的跑步俱乐部还可以保留自己喜欢的曲目，步道和其他奔跑友好的地点的清单。

检查地图

我在随机状态下打开了Google地图，搜索了“高中”，并放大了每个人，以查看它们是否有轨道。在不到一分钟的时间内找到了这一点。图片来源：Google地图

椭圆形跑道很容易在地图上发现。 I found another track near me just by looking for oval shapes on the Strava global heatmap (it highlights popular running routes).像我上面一样，在Google Maps上的卫星视图是寻找附近曲目的另一种好方法。大多数法规大小的室外跑道围绕着足球或足球场，通常会在学校或有时是公园或社区中心。它们将是长方形的形状，在末端弯曲，通常在缩放时可见红色橡胶表面和白色车道线。

您可能还会在运动场或公园中找到非标准的轨道；它们通常是砾石浮出水面的，可能完全不到四分之一英里。我可以想到一个为0.2英里的人，而我见过的几英里是半英里。 While I was traveling, I used maps to find this 1.125-mile running path in a Delaware park that used to be a horse racing track.

在赛道上跑步的规则是什么？

一旦到达轨道，您可能会与所有台词，人跑来跑去以及书面和未写的规则的存在感到有些困惑。不过，确实没有很多礼节要担心。 We have a full track etiquette guide here , but here are the main things you need to know:

阅读规则

首先，检查是否有任何发布的规则或小时数。学校的曲目通常在上课时间对公众开放，但这仍然意味着晚上，周末和假期休息是公平的比赛。 Don't expect that every school's track will always be open, though.私立学校可能不会向公众开放，公立学校仍可能设定时间表或关闭活动的轨道。如果赛道是公园，健身房或社区中心的一部分，请查看其网站或致电以确认可以使用该曲目以及何时使用曲目。

留在你的车道

一旦到达那里，最重要的规则是留在车道上（如果有标记的车道）。想想它们像高速公路上的车道：如果您给他们足够的空间，您可以通过某人，然后在更换车道之前始终看着您。不要通过停在中间来阻挡车道；如果您想坐下来伸展，请找到一个赛道的位置。

人们将在最内向的车道上跑步，如果您要快速冲刺，也可以使用此车道。但是，当您走路或热身时，您应该留在外线。

走正确的方向

在轨道上，通常每个人都逆时针（向左转）。无论如何，这是竞争的标准。一些曲目，尤其是室内的曲目，会张贴一个迹象，表明在星期二和周四（或其他），每个人都朝着相反的方向发展。做其他人在做的事。 If for some reason you feel you must run a different direction than others, make sure to stay to the outside, out of everyone's way.

您如何在赛道上进行跑步锻炼？

曲目有您想做的任何事情，因此没有特定的过程。但是，作为一般规则，您将把要做的工作分解成可衡量的小块。一圈的监管轨道（在最内向的车道中测量）为400米，几乎完全四分之一英里。

整个赛道上不断慢跑是完全可以的，但是更多的人会使用轨道进行间隔工作。您快速行驶很短的距离，然后在呼吸时步行以恢复或站立。然后再进行另一个快速间隔，然后重复该过程，直到准备回家为止。

这是对初学者友好的锻炼，您可以在赛道上第一次进行：

  1. 围绕赛道（1英里）的四圈热身。这可以是轻快的步行，缓慢，轻松的慢跑或两者的混合。您想完成这一步骤，感觉很热身并准备好工作，而不是精疲力尽。

  2. 沿曲目的弯曲部分行走（大约100米）。

  3. 运行轨道的直线部分（这也约为100米）。不要全力以赴，只要保持强劲，快速的步伐即可。

  4. 根据需要重复步骤2和第3步。一英里的价值（四圈）将为您提供八个100米的跑步，这是第一天的良好锻炼。您可以稍后再做。

  5. 慢跑至少一两圈以冷却，如果您愿意，更多。

跑步者将上述锻炼称为“ 8 x 100”，因为您正在进行八次100米跑步。 （在两者之间行走被认为是恢复。）这是间隔的常见距离：

  • 100 m（赛道的直截了当）

  • 200 m（曲线加一条直线或轨道的一半）

  • 400 m（一圈）

  • 800 m（两圈）

在锻炼的运行部分之间，您可以休息或步行大约花费的时间大约花费的时间。例如，如果您在大约两分钟内跑一圈（400米），那么您再休息了两分钟，然后再进行。

; https://lifehacker.com/best-ways-ways-to-find-a-running-track-near-you?utm_medium=rss贝丝·斯克瓦雷基（Beth Skwarecki）Fitness 如何离线使用三星Galaxy AI 01JMMMQ3EY9AVA10S410BS49CB Mon, 24 Feb 2025 13:30:00 +0000想要使用Galaxy AI，但也关心您的隐私吗？您可以在设备上进行一些AI功能。

Starting with the Galaxy S24 series, Samsung has started a big push for Galaxy AI on its devices, adding features like Live Translate and Note Assist to all of its most recent mobile releases.在大多数情况下，这些AI驱动的功能都会在云中处理，以便更有效地工作。

但是，希望尝试尝试Galaxy AI的功能但不希望将其数据发送给三星的云服务器来做到这一点的隐私用户有一种方法。这是为三星的Galaxy AI功能启用设备处理的方法。

为什么为Galaxy AI启用设备处理？

实现Galaxy AI的设备处理的最大原因是隐私。通过在Galaxy设备上本地处理与Galaxy AI的所有互动，它可以确保您的数据不会被其他人看到。 That includes any hackers who might manage to work their way into Samsung's servers, but as a side bonus, processing locally also means these features will be able to work offline .

三星的诺克斯技术和个人数据引擎在这里特别有用。我将从诺克斯开始。这是一个针对企业客户的较旧的安全平台，可保护存储在三星设备上的个人数据免受恶意攻击。自诺克斯（Knox）首次推出以来，某些功能已经滴入了三星面向消费者的产品（例如Galaxy S Phones），这有助于确保您的本地数据安全。

Meanwhile, Personal Data Engine just launched with the Samsung Galaxy S25 series.此设备功能可以从各种应用程序中分析您的数据，以了解您的偏好和使用模式，因此可以用于AI驱动功能而无需将您连接到云（也可以与基于云的应用程序一起使用），但这就是这里不太重要）。虽然听起来可能不像收集个人数据有助于隐私的功能，但使用Knox的加密方法对所有收集的数据进行了加密和安全保存，这是一个不错的妥协，可以使更多的数据从Galaxy AI中获得更多用途，而无需将您的数据发送到其他地方。

如何启用Galaxy AI开发处理

To enable Galaxy AI on-device processing, open Settings on your Galaxy phone. Next, scroll down until you find Galaxy AI . At the bottom, you'll see a toggle to Process data only on device .

打开它，以下Galaxy AI功能将仅交换为本地处理：

  • Browsing assist : Summarize, Read highlights aloud

  • Call assist : Live translate

  • Writing assist : Chat translation, Composer, Style and grammar, Suggested replies

  • 口译员

  • Note assist : Translate, Transcribe

  • Photo assist : Sketch to edit, Portrait studio

  • Transcript assist : Transcribe, Translate, Summary

因此，您现在正在本地处理，尽管注意到所有功能（例如草图到图像）都可以脱机。此外，对于脱机工作的功能，禁用云连接可能会使结果稍慢。

AI is everywhere these days , but when you see an article online from what has historically been a trusted source, it's reasonable to think an AI wasn't involved. At major newsrooms across the country, though, that reality is increasingly becoming less clear cut.

While not every use of AI in the newsroom is as blatant as an AI just drafting a post onto a blank page (although that happens too ,) it's important to know just how the sausage is being made when it comes to the information that's shaping your worldviews.

Here are just a few news outlets that have started openly using AI in their processes, so you can stay informed about where exactly the information you're reading is coming from.

The New York Times

Earlier this week, Semafor published an article about new AI tools that New York Times management is reportedly encouraging staffers to try. While the publication's legal arm is currently embroiled in a lawsuit against OpenAI and Microsoft for copyright infringement, it appears the site's editorial and product wings are ready to embrace AI in the newsroom, at least going by communication from the top.

According to Semafor's writeup, NYT management is now supplying AI training to its journalists, debuting an internal AI tool called “Echo,” and approving usage of external AI tools including Google's Vertex AI, a few Amazon AI products, and ironically, Microsoft's Copilot and a non-ChatGPT tool from OpenAI.

Not all of these will be used for the website's articles—the New York Times is bigger than what you see on its front page—but Semafor did say that journalists are being encouraged to “use these AI tools” for tasks like mild content revisions or coming up with questions to ask during interviews.

“Generative AI can assist our journalists in uncovering the truth and helping more people understand the world,” read the company's editorial guidelines on AI , which are public on its site. “We view the technology not as some magical solution but as a powerful tool.”

To that end, there are seemingly still some guardrails still in place. Semafor says the NYT has warned staff not to use AI to draft or significantly revise articles, and has noted that AI use could potentially infringe on copyright or unintentionally expose sources.

Still, with internal communication suggesting writers use AI to come up with headlines and draft social copy, it's worth keeping hallucination in mind the next time you see a suspicious-seeming NYT story going viral on social media.

For the journalists' part, Semafor reports that some remain skeptical, worrying that AI in the newsroom could inspire “laziness” and reduce accuracy or creativity.

石英

First off, a disclaimer. Quartz is currently owned by G/O Media, which also owned Lifehacker prior to its sale to Ziff Davis in 2023.

With that said, G/O Media has since then become a major proponent of AI in the newsroom , with business news outlet Quartz being its biggest experiment in this.

Scroll through Quartz' bylines for a bit and you'll find posts attributed to the Quartz Intelligence Newsroom , which seems to be dropping any of the restraints adopted by the New York Times. Here, the AI “writer” has been quietly generating earning reports for months and has recently started spitting out more general blogs as well. These include stories about potential Bitcoin value or how to delete your Meta-owned social media accounts , but as you might expect, there are issues to be aware of with each.

To Quartz' credit, it does not hide that these stories are AI-generated and the AI cites its sources, but it doesn't appear as if there's human oversight addressing any problems that might arise from this.

For instance, the Quartz article on how to delete your Meta-owned social media accounts seems to be a simple regurgitation of a TechCrunch story (which did not give permission to be summarized, for what it's worth), but with clear instructions swapped for what the cribbed TechCrunch writer calls “vague” gestures in the right direction. Speaking about other stories written by the Quartz AI, the same writer also said “my editor would never let me publish something so sloppy.”

With that, it's very likely you might find this story hoping for useful advice, only to leave disappointed and more confused than when you came. But the chances of that only get higher if you land on another story with a less reliable source than TechCrunch.

As noted by Futurism , the Intelligence Newsroom has frequently cited a site called Devdiscourse, which itself has all the appearances of an AI content farm. When robots are citing robots, I do have to ask: why not just go to ChatGPT and prompt it yourself? Even if I accept AI news as worthwhile, it's unclear to me what G/O's efforts are adding here.

G/O is slapping a disclaimer on all AI-generated Quartz stories that says it's in the “first phase of an experimental new version of reporting,” but with AI efforts at the company going back to 2023 , it's unclear if it'll ever figure out what that experiment is supposed to yield.

In the meantime, keep an eye out on all Quartz bylines, and if you sniff AI, maybe consider giving the sources the bot is blending up for you a read instead. It seems like once you click that attractive headline, you're basically playing a game of roulette.

AP

If the New York Times is just starting to dip its toes into AI, and Quartz has done a full-on cannonball, then the AP's use of AI seems to be somewhere in between. On its site, the agency proudly declares that it uses AI for translation, transcription, headlines, research, and even some automated articles, but general blogs are still left to human hands.

“Our goal is to give people a good way to understand how we can do a little experimentation but also be safe,” said AP's Vice President of News Standards and Inclusion, Amanda Barret, in 2023, when the group first issued its guidelines on artificial intelligence .

Where this will most likely affect you is in the site's use of Wordsmith, an AI program that specializes in summarizing content like sports scores, weather reports, and, as with Quartz, earnings. AP has been using a version of this program since 2014 , so it's not exactly new, but it's worth being aware that stories on these topics without a specific author attached likely came from a bot. But aside from these stories, AP's only other clear use of directly AI-written content was an experiment with reporting public safety incidents in a specific Minnesota newspaper .

Otherwise, the only time you're likely to see direct AI content on an AP story is its story summarizing pilot: for instance, AI might put a blurb under election day stories to say which offices are up for grabs.

Again, headlines and research are still admittedly AI-assisted, so it's important to be extra careful when something doesn't pass your sniff test, but it seems like humans are still taking the forefront here, at least for now.

华盛顿邮报

The Washington Post's use of AI is unique, in that it doesn't directly impact the content. Rather, it's more of an enhanced search engine for readers who go looking for it. The bot, called “ Ask the Post AI ,” takes questions, spits out a brief AI-generated response trained on Washington Post content, and then lists relevant articles below in a Google-like manner.

“Answers are AI-generated from published reporting,” warns the bot when you ask a question. “Please verify by consulting the provided articles.”

Responses seem to aim for a measured tone, leaning on quotes from noteworthy sources in matters of opinion, and when I asked the bot about President Trump's evolving stance on TikTok or Elon Musk's history with Tesla, I got truthful responses back, although the former was a paragraph long while the latter was only a sentence long. I suppose how detailed your responses are depends on how much the paper has covered a specific topic.

Washington Post hasn't been clear about which AI tech powers Ask the Post AI, but in general, it won't bother you unless you go looking for it. Based on the prevalent warnings about its use, it seems to be intended more as a place to start research than as a direct news replacement.
